Award.AwardTitle: CRPA: Into the Rift: A Multimedia Experience for Advancing Ecosystem-based Science Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Connecting Researchers to Public Audiences project plans to create a multimedia website, Into the Rift, a virtual journey to Lake Tanganyika in East Africa, along with teaching resources and a dissemination campaign. The content will focus on the high freshwater diversity of the 2nd largest lake in the world; the diverse array of cichlid fish in the lake; and the effects of overharvesting and global warming on the lake's ecosystem. The project's intended learning outcomes are that viewers will have enhanced awareness and understanding of: 1) the ecosystem-scale processes that support life in lakes; 2) the importance of intact natural ecosystems for the well-being of human societies; 3) the techniques that scientists use to learn more about the ecosystem-scale movement of matter and energy; and 4) potential career paths in STEM fields. These learning outcomes correlate to the current and proposed science standards, which provide a structure for content development and outcomes assessment.

The project will be designed by the collaboration of an ecologist (the PI Dr. Yvonne Vadeboncoeur), education specialist (co-PI Dr. Lisa Kenyon), communication specialist (co-PI Dr. Elliot Gaines) all from Wright State University, and a media lab (Habitat Seven), and informed by formative evaluation conducted by Edu, Inc. The website, hosted by a guide from East Africa along with the PI, will be presented in three languages (Spanish, French, and Swahili) in addition to English. Edu, Inc. will also conduct a summative evaluation of all the components of the project with respect to the four intended learning outcomes and their related concepts as well as analyze the outcomes of the dissemination strategies.

This CRPA uses internet technologies to make abstract scientific concepts and a largely inaccessible research location available to a wide audience. The project intends to inform and engage the audience with an aggressive use of social media in addition to the website. Into the Rift will provide material for both the lay audience and classrooms, including access to authentic scientific data to compare the Lake Tanganyika data to environmental data collected from the U.S. Great Lakes. Additional collaborations with established organizations, including Crossing Boundaries, Conservation Bridge and Community Bridges, will expand the reach and impact of the project to diverse audiences. The multi-lingual approach extends the reach to potentially an even greater audience both within and outside the U.S.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Humans can live on Earth because of the organisms and ecosystems that provide us with the food we eat, the air we breathe, and the clean water that we drink. Colonizing Mars would realistically require that recreate many of those ecosystems, but most citizens of this planet are unaware of the essential role of well-functioning ecosystems in every aspect of human existence. Ecosystem ecologists study how the living and non-living parts of the Earth interact to provide the ecosystem services upon which we depend. Ecosystem scientists have to be adept at thinking like a chemist, a physicist and a biologist all at the same time, and many of the processes that ecosystem ecologists study seem intangible and esoteric. Sometimes it seems as if the inaccessibility and complexity of ecosystem science is rivaled only by its importance to humans. Climate change, harmful algal blooms, loss of soil fertility and invasive species are problems that ecosystem scientists can help solve. The Into the Rift website was designed to help citizens understand how ecosystems support us. We demonstrate this by diving into the processes that sustain life in a biologically rich and fascinating aquatic ecosystem in East Africa – Lake Tanganyika. Furthermore, we hope the website inspires young people of all backgrounds to consider careers in science, especially ecosystem science.

With the Into the Rift website, we created a web-based proxy for the experience of traveling to a research station on the shores of Lake Tanganyika, where scientists are making discoveries related to climate change, ecosystem ecology, and freshwater biodiversity. These discoveries can make a difference for the well-being of people who rely on the lake as a source of food and income.

Students are taken on a ‘virtual journey’ where they can direct their own exploration of lake biodiversity and the local communities that depend on the lake, and get to know the scientists who conduct their research in this biologically unique place.

Into the Rift is designed to be enjoyed by a wide public audience, with teacher resources available to help educators interested in bringing the journey into their classrooms. Into the Rift provides a compelling digital proxy for an excursion to a biologically fascinating corner of the world. It’s designed to vivify principles of ecosystem ecology that are abstract and otherwise easily overlooked while showcasing how ecological science is done. The goal of Into the Rift is twofold: First, to provide a foundation from which to cultivate an appreciation of field-based science. Second, to reveal the link between functioning ecosystems and human well-being. 

The Into the Rift website has an associated curriculum targeted towards students 16 years old and older. The curriculum is inquiry-based, allowing students to formulate and test hypotheses regarding the needs of different types of organisms, and to explore how climate change affects the fish and algae that live in Lake Tanganyika. Students can use the website to see how scientists conduct research in the field. Then they canconduct their own meaningful research in the classroom.

We encourage you to dive Into the Rift for your own immersive experience.

http://intotherift.org/
